OPEC’s circus is in full swing today, complete with a cast of oil ministers, analysts and hundreds of journalists camped out in Vienna, and I will be honest and say I find it both weirdly fascinating and horrifying, like watching the enactment of some ancient magic ritual. I wonder what a visitor from planet Mars would think?

With Christmas and other holidays coming up, I’ve attached a list of the books that I’ve found most enjoyable and that have had the biggest impact on my thinking in 2016 (with links to Amazon in case you want to buy any of them)

PM11:05am

http://sites.dartm...ision-Nov-2016.pdf

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Abstract. This paper presents the first systematic test of long-standing debates about how much
precision foreign policy analysts can justify when estimating subjective probabilities. Examining
a unique data set containing 888,328 geopolitical forecasts, we demonstrate that qualitative
probability assessments, including lexicons currently employed by national security officials,
systematically sacrifice predictive accuracy. This finding does not depend on extreme forecasts,
short time horizons, particular scoring rules, or question content. “Returns to precision” correlate
more with respondents’ skill, effort, and training in probabilistic reasoning than with their
numeracy, education, or cognitive style. Our results indicate that foreign policy analysts can
parse their judgments more precisely than conventional wisdom supposes and that this ability
can be cultivated. These findings shed light on controversies regarding the limits of subjective
judgment when assessing social phenomena, showing how explicit probability assessments are
empirically justifiable even in domains featuring as much complexity and subjectivity as
predicting world politics

PM11:11am

Got to sell stuff fast

BE11:12am

Incidentally, the smartest thing written about stress tests is (somewhat inevitably) written by Matt Levine.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

The idea of a stress test is, you imagine a stress scenario, you calculate how much each bank would lose in that scenario, and then you calculate how much capital the bank would have left. There is a temptation -- somewhat encouraged by the Federal Reserve's stress tests in the U.S. -- to think that the bank should have left at least enough capital to satisfy its capital requirements. But that is circular. The point of capital is to cushion a bank against losses. Capital requirements should be set high enough that, if the bank had big losses, it would survive. Saying that a bank should meet those requirements after the big losses feels like double-counting.

BE11:12am

From August. https://www.bloomb...s-and-stress-tests

BE11:12am

BE11:23am

11:23 am
PM11:23am

(Pi1010 - I do!)

BE11:23am

Here's RBC.

BE11:23am

RBS screened weakest in the stress test in our view. RBS' CET1 ratio in the stress test fell from 15.5% to 5.9%, below both its hurdle rate of 6.6% and its softer Systemic Reference Point of 7.1%. The numbers do not include the AT1 issuance in August which would increase the CET1 ratio by 78bps if triggered in this scenario. As a result RBS has updated its capital plan which includes an as yet unspecified decreasing of the cost base; run down and sale of other non-core loan portfolios in relation to personal and commercial franchises; reduction in non core commercial portfolios; and proactive management of undrawn facilities. We were expecting another cost plan from RBS at the end of the year consistent with management guidance, but the new capital plan could go deeper than market expectations on RWA reduction. The one positive from the stress test result is that RBS' pillar 2a buffer fell 70bps in Q3- it was the only bank that did not disclose the number at the results, which is a positive surprise and the largest decline of all the large UK banks (STAN increased 60bps; HSBC +30bps; BARC unch; LLOY -10bps). The stressed losses for RBS at 10pp of capital are extremely large in comparison to other banks which we expect is due to conduct risk- the BOE gives the aggreagte conduct losses for the sector at £30bn. We believe the stress test highlights that capital return from RBS is long dated and at significant risk and should therefore not be included in valuations. Our valuation is 160p without excess capital and 204p with excess capital compared to a share price of 192p- we rate RBS Underperform.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Barclays soft fail addressed by existing plans
Barclays stressed minimum CET1 ratio of 6.9% post management actions was below its systemic reference point of 7.8%. However, post the conversion of AT1 it was 8.3% and above the SRP. As Barclays has already announced plans to strengthen capital (the announcement to sell Barclays Africa (BAGL) and completed additional AT1 issuance of £1.1bn) the PRA did not require Barclays to submit a revised capital plan. In this test Barclays saw a 550bp hit to CET1 pre management actions vs. 340bp under the previous stress test. The higher Pillar 2A buffer of 2.3% used in the hurdle rate vs 2.2% given at the 9m results is due to calculating on lower 2015 RWAs. Barclays has already announced a lower dividend for 2016 and 2017 so we don’t see any implications for dividends. For Barclays the issue remains building capital via the continuing Non-Core run-off and the disposal of its stake in BAGL and by 2018E we forecast a 14.3% CET1.
There remains a number of moving parts here especially litigation costs and the final benefit and timing of a disposal of BAGL, which explains why Barclays is not given credit for any excess capital in valuation.

BE11:24am

STAN did not meet its tier 1 capital requirement but on a CET1 basis is above both the hurdle rate and the Systemic Reference Point post management actions - as such the fail is not as weak as RBS' in our view. There is no updated capital plan as STAN's current plans are adequate to address the tier 1 shortfall. The BOE is conducting 2 stress tests next year and in 2017 the focus will be on weak global supply growth; persistently low interest rates; and a continuation in declines in world trade. As a global trade bank we would not expect STAN to fare well in this type of environment. There are very low dividend or excess capital expectations for STAN currently with no dividend expected this year and a small dividend in 2017 and this stress test result is unlikely to change that expectation in our view.

Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 213.30, down 0.95 (-0.44%), High: 215.85, Low: 211.85, Volume: 10.59m

BE11:26am

Expect Lloyds to increase dividends post this result: Lloyds CT1 ratio declined from 12.8% (FY15) to 10.3% post management actions in the stress scenario which was significantly above the 7.0% hurdle rate. The net drawdown of 2.5% was the second smallest amongst the banks stress tested after Santander UK. The strong stress test performance from Lloyds re-affirms its strong capital and balance sheet position. As a result, we believe that Lloyds remains well placed to increase dividend distributions at 4Q’16.

BE11:26am

And on HSBC .....

11:26 am
HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 630.90, down 0.9 (-0.14%), High: 635.90, Low: 627.90, Volume: 6.07m
BE11:26am

HSBC’s buybacks remain underpinned: HSBC CT1 ratio declined from 11.9% (FY15) to 9.1% post management actions in the stress scenario which was above the 6.1% hurdle rate and 7.3% SRP. The net drawdown for HSBC was 2.8% in the stress test. HSBC stock trades at 1.1x P/TNAV and the group has already indicated for buybacks potentially continuing into 2017. We already expect the group to announce another $2.5bn buyback in 2017 but at current valuations of 1.1 P/TNAV, we see limited upside.

BE11:31am

BE11:32am

11:33 am
BE11:33am

I'm not saying there's anything amiss here. It just all looks spectacularly complicated. Have a search of registrations to their head office at Breakspear Park if you're interested at all.

BE11:34am

Back to the results though. Decent numbers, no 2017 warning.

BE11:34am

Here's Goodbody.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Britvic reported FY16 EBITA of £183m which is c.2% ahead of forecast. The key driver of the beat was a strong Q4 performance in the GB Carbs, with fixed costs also slightly better than forecast. In terms of outlook, while management acknowledge that FY17 will be difficult given input cost inflation and sugar tax headwinds, it expects to deliver a result in-line with market expectations.

BE11:35am

GB Carbs delivered a strong year in FY16 with underlying revenue growth of +5.2%, with a particularly strong outturn in Q4 (+13%). Growth was driven by the Pepsi Max brand which continues to take share. The division also benefitted from the rollout of the Subway contract, with the Group’s range available in over 2000
outlets.

BE11:35am

Overall, GB Stills performance was challenged in FY16, with total sales down 7.1% on an underlying basis. This was related to: i) the removal of the added sugar Robinson’s variant; and ii) a generally difficult market backdrop. Importantly, however, the Group’s lfl sales performance improved sequentially in Q4 (-2.3% vs -10.3% in Q3) as it cycled the removal of the added sugar range.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

And Barclays .............

BE11:36am

First impressions:

· FY16 results were a beat at sales and EPS, driven by very strong performance in GB Carbs. FY sales were +3.3% ahead of consensus, with organic sales growth 0.4%, vs consensus -0.3% and BARC -0.6%. EBITA was 1.7% ahead and adjusted EPS was 3.6% ahead of consensus. The dividend was 24.5p vs. cons. 23.9p (BARC 24.2p);

· The outlook looks fine with EBITA guidance in line with consensus. As expected management highlight the challenging trading backdrop in FY17 given input cost inflation and Brexit, but encouragingly they are confident that they can mitigate these through revenue management and cost savings initiatives and also highlight that FY17 trading has started well;

· Divisionally, GB Carbs was again the star of the show with Q4 OSG accelerating to 13.5%, helped by share gain in Pepsi, positive mix from single serve and the Subway contract win. The new year has started well, with Nielsen data for the 4wks ended 5 Nov shows GB Carbs value up c. 5% and continued outperformance vs Coke (-0.7%) and the CSD category (+0.9%). Decline in GB Stills moderated to c. 2% in Q4 and was in line with our estimate, as the group began to cycle the removal of the Robinsons full sugar variant. Ireland OSG was broadly in line (Q4 OSG +4.8%) while France Q4 OSG of +3.0% was ahead due to better weather in late Q4. International performance was below our estimate given weakness in Europe particularly in Benelux, while Brazil FY revenue of £89.5m was 5.6% ahead of our forecast.

BE11:36am

Britvic trades on a CY17E P/E of 11.7.x, close to 10-year PE relative lows against Staples and the FTSE 250

11:36 am

So there's the reason for the rally. It was less than 12 times.

Capita PLC (CPI:LSE): Last: 529.50, down 28 (-5.02%), High: 542.50, Low: 521.00, Volume: 2.46m
PM11:37am

BE11:37am

Which I think is the worst-performing FTSE 100 stock this year

11:37 am

BE11:38am

Anyway, down today because HSBC's negative.

BE11:39am

Talking about the divi at risk or, potentially, a cash call.

11:39 am
PM11:39am

hmm

BE11:39am

On bullet points, the argument looks strikingly similar to the Serco one pre last year's rights issue.

PM11:40am

Well that's not comforting

11:40 am
BE11:40am

And as always with cash calls, it's a question of "go big and go early" or "muddle through"

BE11:41am

Let me grab the first page here. HSBC's services team's very good, generally speaking.

BE11:41am

The shares have more than halved since the last profit warning (on 29 September 2016). Many investors are asking if the shares have hit a trough; we see a material risk that they have not. A high financial gearing (2.7x net debt/EBITDA), declining sales and a weak growth outlook is a combination that seldom fuels investor confidence. Consensus estimates (-1 to -2% organic sales decline and +40bps EBITDA margin) for 2017 also seem optimistic. Our EPS estimates are 8-9% below consensus, with DPS 50% below consensus.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

We see three strategic choices for Capita: a slow de-gearing (limited progress on M&A and dividend), disposal of underperforming business, and/or capital increase. A slow, organic de-gearing does not look like a realistic option to us. The UK public sector pipeline is weak, private sector contract awards and decision making have come to screeching halt post the Brexit vote, according to the company. The transactional businesses such as the recruitment business, the share registry, and the IT box shifting sales are unlikely to cyclically swing back to growth soon. If the decline in organic sales worsens further, financial de-gearing may not happen. A highly geared balance sheet in a weak demand environment may impede further long-duration contract wins. The IFRS rule changes (due Jan 2019), which require companies to capitalise operating leases (cGBP600m or 0.8x additional gearing for Capita), will only make matters worse for commercial purposes. None of these are helpful for a recovery scenario to play out in the short run. We think the balance sheet needs to de-gear and Capita needs to look at pre-emptive steps including disposals, dividend cuts and/or capital increase.

BE11:42am

There's a lot in here too about quality of earnings, which has been a theme for a while.

PM11:43am

indeed

11:43 am
BE11:43am

As in, rising capital intensity, rising accruals, rising capex ......

BE11:43am

..... Reliance on acquisitions of sometimes questionable quality.

BE11:44am

You know the themes. Anyway, target 450p on that.

11:44 am

PM11:44am

11:44 am
PM11:44am

The stock's up

PM11:44am

PM11:45am

11:44 am
PM11:45am

PM11:45am

They've selected which numbers to release

PM11:45am

Berlin, November 30, 2016 – Rocket Internet SE´s (“Rocket Internet” or “the Company”)
selected companies continued on the path towards profitability. For the first nine months
2016, the aggregate adjusted EBITDA margin improved significantly at all selected
companies from a weighted average of -34.4% in the first nine months 2015 to -17.5%. The
selected companies continued to grow revenues, whilst absolute EBITDA losses decreased
by EUR 159 million.

11:45 am
PM11:45am

How does that work? They're an incubator and they just choose which portfolio companies to issue details on

PM11:46am

If i was a shareholder I'd go nuts

PM11:46am

https://www.rocket...ressrelease_q3.pdf

11:46 am
PM11:46am

Have a look at this presentation

PM11:47am

https://www.rocket...resentation_q3.pdf

PM11:47am

Anyway, our fav Stick watcher, Neil Campling, has gone through the numbers that have actually been released

11:47 am
PM11:47am

Rocket Internet’s selected financials for the quarter ending September 30th are accompanied by an updated LPV calculation the most important KPI. Problem is the LPV data has details for seven portfolio companies, substantially fewer than the past. And the financial details exclude Delivery Hero which accounts for 29% of the published LPV data. In September at the time of the 1H results Rocket reported a Group LPV of EUR5.12B. This morning, the data as of November shows a Group LPV of EUR 3.71B, although again the LFL comparison is difficult to tally as valuation metrics have been removed for a number of companies. Furthermore some of the companies within the Rocket Internet network also provide investors with so-called downround protections rights which could dilute Rocket’s own holdings if these rights are triggered.

PM11:48am

9M data shows an improvement of 35% aggregate GMV growth, 32% net revenue growth and adjusted EBITDA margins of -17.5% from -34.4% for the 9M 2016 compared to the first 9M of 2015. However, the same masks slowing improvements. At the 6M comparison point AMV growth reported was 38%, revenue growth was similar at 32%, but adjusted EBITDA margins had improved to -16.7%.

PM11:48am

Within the detail 3Q 2016 EBITDA loss at Hello Fresh of EUR20.5M compares to a loss of EUR30.9M for 3Q 2015. This equates to an improvement of -36.2% adjusted EBITDA margin to -14% but is helped by a significant change in depreciation of property, plant and equipment and amortization of intangible assets (Q3 2015: EUR 0.2m; Q3 2016: EUR 1.1m). And the trade off for growth continues. While the 9M net revenue growth reported a LFL increase of 121% this slowed considerably to 71.6% for 3Q16.

11:48 am
PM11:48am

FoodPanda continues to post high losses with net revenue of EUR 14.7M in 3Q16 at an adjusted EBITDA margin of -85.7% and a cash position which has shrunk from EUR 94.4M at the end of September 2015 to EUR 57.5M at the end of September 2016. However, the ‘selected companies’ adjusted EBITDA margins headlines of significant improvements to an average of -17% from an average of -34% masks the fact Food Panda’s adjusted EBITDA margin is based on GMV rather than the net revenue basis used for all other selected companies. And, of course, this is without Delivery Hero being a selected company and hence no financial data of margins or EBITDA despite a significant contribution to LPV and revenues (9M 2016 revenue of EUR 229M).

PM11:48am

Summary...

PM11:48am

With weak business momentum, opaque funding structures, concerns over the ability for portfolio companies to scale profitably and the ongoing risk of downrounds in portfolio companies we remain sellers of Rocket Internet.

11:48 am
PM11:48am

Does Goldman still cover this thing?

PM11:48am

Havent seen anything from them on it in a while

PM11:49am

Maybe just quietly dropped it

11:48 am
PM11:49am

BE11:49am

BE11:49am

Dunno what's happened since.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Also ... not being a Rocket scientist, I'd innocently imagined that "proven winners" was an fixed category.

BE11:50am

I'm unsure why shareholders benefit from it not being so.

BE11:50am

Here's Deutsche's summary, for what it's worth.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Overall, continued solid progress on reducing EBITDA losses - but arguably at the expense of top-line growth - especially at HelloFresh - which, however, we believe is mainly due to seasonal effects rather than structural issues. Overall, solid execution by management, in our view, but it likely needs a value crystallization event, i.e. an IPO or trade sale, to trigger a change in market sentiment.

BE11:51am

HelloFresh revenues came in at EUR147m, 6% below our forecasts, and likely the main bear point today. This marks a moderate sequential decline in revenues (EUR150m in Q2) but we note that Q2/Q3 are seasonally weak quarters (due to holiday season) and we remain constructive growth rates can accelerate in Q4. The positive news is that profitability continued to improve, i.e. EBITDA of EUR -25m (in-line with DBe EUR-24m) and implying a margin of -15% after -36% in Q3'15. Delivery Hero reported revenues of EUR229m in 9M, up a strong 68% yoy (DBe of EUR226m) and is well on track to reach its full-year revenue target of more than EUR300m in our view. Home24 and Westwing saw improving profitability but with mixed revenue growth.

Curious to have GFG reporting ahead of RKET. GFG the aggregation of five regional brands, in order of scale, Dafiti (LATAM), Lamoda (Russia), Zalora/The Iconic (SE Asia and Australia) and Namshi (Middle East). RKET owns 20.4%, less material following the write-down; now contributes c.€210m to the NPV.

At GFG, Q316 revenue €255m, +22.2% YoY at c/c, adjusted EBITDA margin (12.9%). At GFG level and within each brand, Q316 growth off the 9M16 pace and the 9M16 pace off FY15. Growth is slowing. At the same time, the adjusted EBITDA loss is moderating, Namshi EBITDA positive, +2.9%, but there does seem to be a somewhat disconcerting dynamic in that revenue growth is waning as GFG pushes to adjusted EBITDA breakeven at GFG level. Where does that end?

Shore summarises where we are.

BE11:55am

Lenders receive internal approvals for refinancing of entire bank debt; revised maturity profile aligned with POG’s expected cash generation and growth capex plans. POG’s lenders have been received formal internal approvals for the refinancing of POG’s entire bank debt of US$529.8m. The proposed terms include an effective interest rate of c.8% and a revised maturity profile from May 2018 to September 2022 (2018: US$55.5m; 2019: US$122m; 2020: US$93.5m; 2021: US$124.7m; 2022: US$93.5m) is aligned with POG’s production profile, expected cash generation and growth capex plans.

According to POG, the proposed refinancing allows it to self-fund the strategically-important POX Hub project out of free cash flow, with current plans calling for commissioning by end 2018. The proposed joint venture process with GMD Gold is no longer being pursued but the parties remain “in constructive discussions” to establish whether an alternative mutually-beneficial arrangement can be arrived at.

The refinanced bank debt will apparently include an option “to extend from 2019 to 2022”. We weren’t clear as to what this meant, given the repayment schedule outlined in the press release was for up to 2022. But anyway, this option has the following conditions precedent: operational completion of the pressure oxidation (POX) plant in 2019; total consolidated Net Debt/EBITDA ratio for the 12 months ending June 2019 of ≤2.5:1; and evidence of funds or confirmation that convertible bonds due 2020 will be rapid in full via conversion into equity, or that the maturity is extended and subordinated to the bank debt.

BE11:57am

It’s an interesting week for POGs. First plunging temperatures combined with regional flooding caused fractures in pit benches at the main Andreevskaya pit restricting mining and blasting. The company’s other pits were dryer and no so affected by the sudden freeze.
It appears the sudden freezing of the groundwater caused the fracturing of rock compromising stability in the Andreevskaya pit.
This will impact gold production and may make compromise this quarter’s production target.
POGs also report the refinancing of $530m of bank debt. with Sberbank and VTB subject to final documentation.
“The approved terms include a revised maturity profile from May 2018 to September 2022 (inclusive of option to extend the 2019 maturity payment to 2022 upon certain conditions being satisfied) and effective average interest rate of c.8%.”
“The extended maturity profile of borrowings is now successfully aligned with the Company's production profile, expected cash generation and growth capital expenditure plans.”
The lenders have also agreed to support the development of the Pressure Oxidation Project.
Conclusion: We wonder if the pit stability problems at the Andreevskaya pit might have any impact on the terms and conditions of the refinancing.
